title: 103_hr2513
content: The Military Selective Service Act is repealed. The Military Selective Service Act is repealed, and assets, contracts, property, and records held by the Selective Service System will be transferred to the Administrator of General Services. The Office of Selective Service Records will not be reestablished, and employees will be assisted in transferring to other positions in the executive branch. Conforming amendments are made to Title 5 of the United States Code. The Military Selective Service Act is amended by removing certain sections, and the Immigration and Nationality Act is also amended. The Selective Training and Service Act of 1940 and the Selective Service Act of 1948 are amended by removing certain sections related to military service. The Immigration and Nationality Act is also amended to make changes to eligibility criteria. In the amendments, certain sections related to military service are removed from the Selective Training and Service Act of 1940 and the Selective Service Act of 1948. Changes are also made to eligibility criteria in the Immigration and Nationality Act. Certain sections related to military service are removed from the Selective Training and Service Act of 1940 and the Selective Service Act of 1948. Changes are made to eligibility criteria in the Immigration and Nationality Act by striking out specific provisions. Changes are made to the Selective Service Act by removing certain sections related to military service eligibility criteria. Changes are made to the Selective Service Act by removing sections related to military service eligibility criteria, including the assignment to the Selective Service System. Changes are made to various titles including Title 22, Title 26, and Title 28, by repealing certain sections and amending others to reflect the provisional acceptance of individuals for specific duties. Title 28 of the United States Code is amended to specify the active duty status of magistrates with the Armed Forces. Additionally, the Job Training Partnership Act is revised by removing certain sections. Title 37 and Title 38 of the United States Code are amended to remove certain sections related to the Military Selective Service Act. The Military Selective Service Act is being amended in Title 42 of the Social Security Act to remove certain provisions related to the satisfactory completion of military service. The Military Selective Service Act is being amended to remove provisions related to military service completion. Section 1007(b) of the Legal Services Corporation Act is also amended to provide legal assistance for desertion cases. The Act and its amendments will take effect 180 days after enactment.
